utterance: The river ! The river ! O borrow  A speed that is swifter Afar  Kentucky ! Haste, haste, thou To-morrow !  Poor lads, dreaming not of the sorrow,  The anguish of war.
speaker: THE OTHER

utterance: Do the worst, ye rebels, that ye can do  To the train that follows, but / go through !
speaker: narrator

utterance: Madam, your place  Will soon be noisy, for at yonder town  We take on other soldiers. If you change  Your seat and join that little lady, then  It will not seem so lonely or so strange  For you, as here among so many men.
speaker: a conductor

utterance: Allow me, mademoiselle,  Our good conductor thinks it would be well  That we should keep together, since the car  Will soon be overcrowded, and we are  The only women. May I have a seat  In this safe little corner by your side ?  Thanks ; it is fortunate, indeed, to meet  So sweet a friend to share the long day's ride !  That is, if yours be long ?
speaker: Helena

utterance: To Benton's Mill.
speaker: the maiden

utterance: I go beyond, not far I think we pass  Your station just before Waunona Hill ;  But both are in the heart of the Blue Grass.  Do you not love that land ?
speaker: Helena

utterance: I do not know  Aught of it.
speaker: the maiden

utterance: Yes ; but surely you have heard  Of the fair plains where the sweet grasses grow,  Just grass, naught else ; and where the noble herd  Of blooded cattle graze, and horses bred  For victory the rare Kentucky speed  That wins the races ?
speaker: Helena

utterance: Yes; I've heard it said  They were good worthy horses. But indeed  I know not much of horses.
speaker: the maiden

utterance: Then the land  The lovely, rolling land of the Blue Grass,  The wild free park spread out by Nature's hand  That scarce an English dukedom may surpass  In velvet beauty while its royal sweep  Over the country miles and miles away,  Dwarfs man-made parks to toys ; the great trees keep  Their distance from each other, proud array
speaker: Helena

utterance: But you will see it.
speaker: Helena

utterance: No ; I cannot stay  But a few hours at most, a single day.
speaker: the maiden

utterance: I think I like the best,  Of all dumb things, a horse of Blue-Grass breed,  The Arab courser of our own new West,  The splendid creature, whose free-hearted speed  Outstrips e'en time itself. Oh ! when he wins  The race, how, pulsed with pride, I wave my hand  In triumph, ere the thundering shout begins,  And those slow, cautious judges on the stand,  Have counted seconds ! Is it not a thrill  That stirs the blood, yet holds the quick breath still ?
speaker: Helena

utterance: I ne'er have seen race-horses, or a race.
speaker: the maiden

utterance: I crave your pardon ; in your gentle face  I read reproof.
speaker: Helena

utterance: I judge not any man.
speaker: the maiden

utterance: Nor woman ?
speaker: Helena

utterance: If you force reply, I can  Speak but the truth. The cruel, panting race,  For gamblers* prizes, seems not worthy place  For women nor for men, indeed, if they  Were purer grown. Of kindred ill the play,  The dinner loud with wine, the midnight dance^  The deadly poison of all games of chance  All these are sinful.
speaker: the maiden

utterance: Ah ! poor sins, how stern  The judge ! I knew ye not for sins I learn  For the first time that ye are evil. Go,  Avaunt ye ! So my races are a woe  Alas ! And David Garrick ! Where's the harm  In David ?
speaker: Helena

utterance: I know not the gentleman.
speaker: the maiden

utterance: Nay, he's a play ; a comedy so warm,  So pitiful, that, let those laugh who can,  / weep. And must I yield my crystal glass,  Dewy with ice, and fragrant with rare wine,  That makes a dreary dinner-party pass  In rosy light, where after-fancies shine  Things that one might have said ? And then the dance,  The valse & deux temps, if your partner chance  To be a lover
speaker: Helena

utterance: Madam, pray excuse  My seeming rudeness ; but I must refuse  To dwell on themes like these.
speaker: the maiden

utterance: Did I begin  The themes, or you ?
speaker: Helena

utterance: But / dwelt on the sin,  And you
speaker: the maiden

utterance: Upon the good. Did I not well ?  I gave you good for evil, mademoiselle.
speaker: Helena

utterance: Forgive me, lady, but I cannot jest,  I bear too anxious heart within my breast ;  One dear to me lies wounded, and I go  To find him, help him home with tender care  To home and health, God willing.
speaker: the maiden

utterance: Is it so ?  Strange but ah ! no. The wounded are not rare,  Nor yet the grief, in this heart-rending war.  But he will yet recover ; I feel sure  That one beloved by heart so good, so pure  As yours, will not be taken. Sweet, your star  Is fortunate.
speaker: Helena

utterance: Not in the stars, I trust.  We are but wretched creatures of the dust,  Sinful, and desperately wicked ; still,  It is in mercy our Creator's will  To hear our prayers.
speaker: the maiden

utterance: And do you then believe  He grants all heart-felt prayers ? One might conceive  A case : Suppose a loving mother prays  For her son's life ; he, worn with life's hard ways,
speaker: Helena

utterance: Entreats his God for death with equal power  And fervor.
speaker: Helena

utterance: It is wrong to pray for death.
speaker: the maiden

utterance: I grant it not. But, say in self-same hour  A farmer prays for rain ; with 'bated breath  A mother, hastening to a dying child,  Prays for fair weather ? But you do not deign  To listen. Ah ! I saw you when you smiled  That little, silver smile ! I might explain  My meaning further ; but why should I shake  Your happy faith ?
speaker: Helena

utterance: You could not.
speaker: the maiden

utterance: Nay, that's true ;  You are the kind that walks up to the stake  Unflinching and unquestioning. I sue  For pardon, and I pray you tell me all  This tale of yours. When did your lover fall  What battle-field?
speaker: Helena

utterance: Not any well-known name ;  It was not Heaven's pleasure that the fame  Of well-known battle should be his. A band  Of wild guerrillas raiding through the land,  Shot him, and left him bleeding by the way.
speaker: the maiden

utterance: Guerrillas ?
speaker: Helena

utterance: Yes ; John Morgan's.
speaker: the maiden

utterance: Maybe so,  And maybe not ; they bear a seven-leagued name  That many hide beneath ; each shot, each blow,  Is trumpeted as theirs, and all the blame  Falls on their shoulders, be it what it may  Now truth, and now but falsehood. Morgan's men  Are bold Kentucky riders ; every glen  Knows their fleet midnight gallop ; every map  Kept by our soldiers here is scored with marks  Where they have been ; now near, now miles away,  From river lowland to the mountain-gap,  Swift as the rushing wind. No watch-dog barks  When they ride by, no well-versed tongues betray
speaker: Helena

utterance: Their resting-place ; Kentucky knows her own,  Gives silent, helpful welcome when they pass  Across her borders north from Tennessee,  Heading their horses for the far Blue Grass,  The land of home, the land they long to see,  The lovely rolling land. We might have known  That come they would !
speaker: Helena

utterance: You are Kentucky-bred ?
speaker: the maiden

utterance: I come from Washington. Nay but I read  The doubt you try to hide. Be frank confess  I am that mythical adventuress  That thrives in Washington these troublous days  The country correspondent's tale ?
speaker: Helena

utterance: Your dress  And something in your air
speaker: the maiden

utterance: I give you praise  For rare sincerity. Go on.
speaker: Helena

utterance: Your tone,  Your words, seem strange. But then, I've never known  A woman like you.
speaker: the maiden

utterance: Yet we are not few,  Thank Heaven, for the world's sake ! It would starve  If gray was all its color, and the dew  Its only nectar. With a pulsing haste  It seeks the royal purples, and draws down  The luscious bunches to its thirsty taste,  And feels its blood hot-thrilled, a regal crown  Upon its brow ; and then, its hands do carve  The vine-leaves into marble.
speaker: Helena

utterance: Did he fall alone,  Your gallant soldier-boy ? And how to you  Came the sad news?
speaker: Helena

utterance: A farmer heard him moan  While passing bore him to the camp, and there
speaker: the maiden

utterance: A captain from our lake-shore wrote me word  Ere the brigade moved on; which, when I heard,  I left my mother, ill, for in despair  He cried, they wrote, for me. He could not know  That they had written, for hot fever drove  His thoughts with whips of flame. O cruel woe,  O my poor love  My Willie !
speaker: the maiden

utterance: Do not grieve, fair child. This day  Will see you by his side nay, if you will,  Then lay your head here weep your grief away.  Tears are a luxury yes, take your fill ;  For stranger as I am, my heart is warm  ,To woman's sorrow, and this woman's arm  That holds you is a loyal one and kind.
speaker: Helena

utterance: Quite calm, again ? That's well.  Wilt taste a peach ? My basket holds a store  Of luscious peaches. Ah ! she weaves a spell,  This lovely sorceress of fruit ; what more  Can man ask from the earth ? There is no cost  Too great for peaches. I have felt surprise  Through all my life that fair Eve should have lost  That mythic Asian land of Paradise  For a poor plebeian apple ! Now a peach,  Pulpy, pink-veined, hanging within her reach,  Might well have tempted her.
speaker: Helena

utterance: Tea-roses ?
speaker: the maiden

utterance: Tangled in your loosened hair  Are roses.
speaker: the maiden

utterance: Sweet child, I pray you tell  Again your budding romance, all the part  Where he first spoke. You'd known him long and well,  Your Willie ?
speaker: Helena

utterance: Yes ; in childhood we had been  Two little lovers o'er the alphabet ;  Then one day I had grown to just sixteen  Down in the apple-orchard there we met,  By chance and
speaker: the maiden

utterance: Nay, you flush  So prettily ! Well, must / tell the rest ?  You knew, then, all at once, you loved him best,  This gallant Willie ?
speaker: Helena

utterance: Yes; then  We were betrothed. I wore his mother's ring,  And Willie joined the church ; before all men  He made the promises and vows which bring  A blessing down from God. Dear lady, strength  From Heaven came to us. Could I endure  This absence, silence, all the weary length  Of hours and days and months, were I not sure  That God was with my Willie ? If on you  Sorrow has fallen, lady (and those tears  Showed me its presence), seek the good, the true,  In this sad life ; a prayer can calm all fears ;  Yield all your troubles to your God's control,
speaker: the maiden

utterance: And He will bless you. Ah ! where should / be  Did I not know that in my Willie's soul  Came first the love of God, then love for me ?
speaker: the maiden

utterance: His love for you comes second?
speaker: Helena

utterance: Would you have  A mortal love come first !
speaker: the maiden

utterance: Sweet heart, I crave  Your pardon. For your gentle Christian zeal  I thank you. Wear this gem 'twill make me feel  That I am something to you when we part.  But what the " silence ?
speaker: Helena

utterance: Ten months (they seem years !)  Since Willie joined the army ; and my heart  Bore it until his letters ceased; then tears  Would come would come !
speaker: the maiden

utterance: Why should the letters cease ?
speaker: Helena

utterance: I know not ; I could only pray for peace,  And his return. No doubt he could not write,  Perplexed with many duties ; his the care  Of a thronged camp, where, ever in his sight,  The new recruits are drilled.
speaker: the maiden

utterance: Had you no doubts ?
speaker: Helena

utterance: Why should I doubt ? We are  Betrothed the same forever, near or far !  He knew my trust  Was boundless as his own.
speaker: the maiden

utterance: But still you must  In reason have known something must have heard  Or else imagined
speaker: Helena

utterance: For three months no word  Until this letter ; from its page I learned  That my poor Willie had but just returned
speaker: the maiden

utterance: To the brigade, when struck down unaware.  It seems he had been three months absent.
speaker: the maiden

utterance: Where ?
speaker: Helena

utterance: They did not say. I hope to bear him home  To-morrow; for in truth I scarce could come,  So ill my mother, and so full my hands  Of household cares ; but, Willie understands.
speaker: the maiden

utterance: But three months so long a time
speaker: Helena

utterance: Were it three years, 'twould be the same. The troth  We plighted, freely, lovingly, from both  Our true hearts came.
speaker: the maiden

utterance: You'll find him, dear ;  All will go well ; take courage. Not severe  His wound ?
speaker: Helena

utterance: Not unto death ; but fever bound  His senses. When the troops moved on, they found  A kindly woman near by Benton's Mill ;  And there he lies, poor Willie, up above  In her small loft, calling, in tones that thrill :  " Oh, come to me, my love, my love, my love !"
speaker: the maiden

utterance: Here is his picture.
speaker: the maiden

utterance: What ! 'tis Meredith !  The girl is mad ! Give it me forthwith !  How came -you by it ?
speaker: Helena

utterance: Madam, you will break  The chain. I beg
speaker: the maiden

utterance: Here is some strange mistake.  This picture shows me Meredith Reid.
speaker: Helena

utterance: Yes, Reid  Is Willie's name ; and Meredith, indeed,
speaker: the maiden

utterance: Is his name also Meredith Wilmer. I  Like not long names, so gave him, lovingly,  The pet name Willie.
speaker: the maiden

utterance: O ye Powers above !  The " pet name Willie !" Would you try to chain  Phoebus Apollo with your baby-love  And baby-titles ? Scarce can I refrain  My hands from crushing you !
speaker: Helena

utterance: You are that girl,  Then, the boy's fancy. Yes, I heard the tale  He tried to tell me ; but it was so old,  So very old ! I stopped him with a curl  Laid playfully across his lips. " Nay, hoid !  Enough, enough," I said; "of what avail  The rest ? I know it all ; 'tis e'er the same  Old story of the country lad's first flame  That burns the stubble out. Now by this spell  Forget it all." He did ; and it was well  He did.
speaker: Helena

utterance: Art faint ?
speaker: Helena

utterance: 'Twill pass. Lady, I enter first  First and alone !
speaker: the maiden

utterance: Child, if I thought his heart  Longed for the sight of you, I'd let you go ;  Nay, I would make you ! As it is  But no,  It cannot be.
speaker: Helena

utterance: Lord, give me strength ! I yield ;  Go you the first. Ah !
speaker: the maiden

utterance:
Yours the nobler part ;  / cannot yield. (And yet it is for him
 THE FARM-HOUSE. 65
  I hold this " cannot " firm.) What might you wield  With that unflinching conscience-power ! See, dim  Mine eyes
  There ; we will go together thus !
 God help us both !
speaker: Helena

utterance: Yes, we have come, we two,  His nearest, dearest. Is it perilous,  The fever ? Where above ? That stair ? We go Come, child come, child.
speaker: Helena

utterance: Dear ladies, you should know  Before
speaker: WOMAN OF THE HOUSE

utterance: Come!
speaker: Helena

utterance: He
speaker: WOMAN OF THE HOUSE

utterance: Child, must I wait for you  Here at his door !
speaker: Helena

utterance: I come ; but something cold  Has touched my heart.
speaker: the maiden

utterance: Then stay, coward !
speaker: Helena

utterance: Nay, hold ;  I come.
speaker: the maiden

utterance: Fate,  You've gained the day at last ! Yes, he is dead !
speaker: Helena

utterance: HE died last night at three quite easily.
speaker: WOMAN OF THE HOUSE

utterance: Alone?
speaker: Helena

utterance: A surgeon from the camp was here.
speaker: WOMAN OF THE HOUSE

utterance: Where is the man ?
speaker: Helena

utterance: Gone back.
speaker: WOMAN OF THE HOUSE

utterance: Send for him.
speaker: Helena

utterance: See,  Here is a trifle ; though it cannot clear  Our debt to you, yet take it.
speaker: Helena

utterance: But you give  Too much.
speaker: WOMAN OF THE HOUSE

utterance: Keep it.
speaker: Helena

utterance:
O Willie ! can I live  Without you ? Love, my love, why are you dead  And I alive ? O noble, golden head,  Whose every curl I know, how still you lie  On this poor pillow, and how dreamlessly  You sleep ! But waken now ; look on me, dear ;  Open those close-shut eyes, for I am here

  Yes, here all this long way from home. Oh, speak  Speak to me, Willie. Ah, how cold his cheek  How icy cold ! O God ! he's dead, he's dead !
speaker: the maiden

utterance: Yes, he is dead, dead as King David. Truth  He was right handsome for a Yankee youth  Rode his horse well.
speaker: WOMAN OF THE HOUSE

utterance: What's this upon the table near his hand ?
speaker: the maiden

utterance: O Lord, I understand  Thy purpose ; 'twas to try my faith. I kneel  To thank thee that mercy doth reveal  The whole to my poor heart. He loved me me,  Me only !
speaker: the maiden

utterance: Would you like to see the wound  Here in his arm ? Why, if she hasn't swooned !
speaker: WOMAN OF THE HOUSE

utterance: Take her below, and care for her, poor child !
speaker: Helena

utterance: Art ill,  Madam ?
speaker: the surgeon

utterance: Thanks, sir. But sorrow cannot kill.  Would that it could ! Nay, I sit by his side  Thus. Now tell all all all.
speaker: Helena

utterance: You cannot hide  The deadly faintness that has paled your cheek ;  Let me get
speaker: the surgeon

utterance: Nothing. Nothing can avail,  Good sir ; my very heart's blood has turned pale.  Struck by God's lightning, do you talk to me  Of faintness ? Only tell your tale speak, speak ;  You saw him die ?
speaker: Helena

utterance: I did ; right tranquilly  He passed away this morning, with your name  Upon his lips for you are Helena ?
speaker: the surgeon

utterance: I am.
speaker: Helena

utterance: I saw your picture.
speaker: the surgeon

utterance: Hair, eyes. What Titian tints !
speaker: the surgeon

utterance: He made me lay  Your letters and your picture on his heart  Before he died ; he would not from them part  For e'en one moment.
speaker: the surgeon

utterance: Lift them not, they're mine ;  My hand alone must touch the holy shrine  Of love and death where the poor relics lie  Darling, because you loved  them !
speaker: Helena

utterance: Let them die,  Go to the grave with him, there on his breast,  Where I would gladly die too be at rest  Forever. And he spake of me ?
speaker: Helena

utterance: He said  That you would come, for he had sent you word.
speaker: the surgeon

utterance: I ne'er received it ; 'twas by chance I heard,  A passing chance.
speaker: Helena

utterance: The lines were down
speaker: the surgeon

utterance: And may  They never rise again that failed that day,  And left him dying here ! Go on ; he said
speaker: Helena

utterance: That you would come, and grieved that o'er his head  The turf might close ere you could reach his side  And give him one last kiss.
speaker: the surgeon

utterance: And then he died.
speaker: Helena

utterance: No more ?
speaker: Helena

utterance: No more. Ah, yes, one other thing :  Short time before, he feebly bade me bring  That package on the table but 'tis torn  Some one has opened it ! It looked well worn,  In old, unbroken foldings when I brought  It from his satchel. Who could thus have wrought  On other's property ?
speaker: the surgeon

utterance: The owner. Then  He said
speaker: Helena

utterance: To give it you, for you would know  Its history, and where it swift should go ;  The name was writ within.
speaker: the surgeon

utterance:
Yes, love ; amen !
 Be it according to thy wish.
speaker: Helena

utterance: Pray take  This fee, good sir. I would that for his sake  Your kindness to him I could send your name  Ringing through all the West in silver fame.  At dawn, you said, the burial ? Then leave  Me here alone with him. I well believe  You'll show me further kindness. Speak no word  Beyond your doctor's art to that poor child  Who weeps below. I would not that she heard  Aught more of grief.
speaker: Helena

utterance:
Ah ! all my passion wild  Has gone ; now come the softening woman tears.  Forgive me, great Creator, that I spake  In my sharp agony. O do thou take  The bitterness from out my soul ; I know  Naught, but thou knowest all ! Then let my woe,  The poor blind woe we short-lived mortals bear,  Be my sad plea.
  I knew, through my despair,  You loved me to the last. Death had no fears  For you, my love ; you met him with my name,  As talisman of the undying flame  That leaps o'er the black chasm of the grave  And mounts to heaven. But I will not rave,  When you died softly.

  Ah ! you love me there  As well as here. God never made me fair  For nothing ; now, I know the gift he gave  That I might take my place with you at last,  Equal in loveliness, though years had passed  Since you first breathed the air above the skies,  The beauty-giving air of paradise.
 Fair are you now, my love, but not like me :  Mine is the goddess-bloom, the rarity  Of perfect loveliness ; yours, the bright charm  Of strong young manhood, whose encircling arm  Could bend me like a reed. Oh, for one clasp  Of that strong arm !
  Hist ! was not that the hasp  Of the old door below ? She comes ; I hear  Her light step on the stair.
  Darling, no fear  Need trouble you upon your couch; to me  A sacred trust this gentle girl shall be  Through life. Did you not love her once ?
speaker: Helena

utterance: Forgiveness thus to leave you here so long ;  I did not mean it, but I swooned away  Before I knew it.
speaker: the maiden

utterance: Thanks. There was no wrong ;  I liked the vigil.
speaker: Helena

utterance:
Sweet those eyes the brow  How calm ! I would not bring life to him now  E'en if I could ; gone to his God at rest  From all earth's toil.
  Dear love, upon thy breast  I lay my hand ; I yield thee back to Him  Who gave thee to me ; and, if thou hast wrought  Wrong to our troth in deed, or word, or thought,  I now forgive thee. Sleep in peace ; the dim,  Dark grave has its awaking.
  As the hart  Longed for the water-brooks, so have I yearned  For token, Willie, that thy love returned  To me at last. Lo ! now I can depart  In peace. My picture, letters ! Thou wast true,  Wast true to me, thank God !
  Madam, to you  I owe apology.
speaker: the maiden

utterance:
Never! But throw

  Your gentle arms around me thus. And so  Give me a blessing.
speaker: Helena

utterance: But I've robbed you you  Who loved him also ; though to me was due  This love of his ; at least
speaker: the maiden

utterance: Sweet doubter, yes ;  I grant thee all. But, as I kneel, O bless  This heart that bows before thee ; all its sin  If it be sin forgive ; and take, within  Thy pure love, me, thy sister, who must live  Long years long years ! O child, who dost forgive  More than thou knowest, lay thy sister-hand  In blessing !
speaker: Helena

utterance: Though I do not understand,  Yet will I thus content thee : Now the Lord  Bless thee, and keep thee by his holy word ;  Be gracious to thee, that thy faith increase ;  Lift up his countenance, and give thee peace,  Now and forever !
speaker: the maiden

utterance: Amen. May it prove  This peace what thou dost think it.
speaker: Helena

utterance:
I must go ;  The horses wait for me. Now that I know  He's safe with God, the living claim my care.  My mother ah, full selfish was the love  That made me leave her so ; I could despair  Of mine own self, if God were not so good,  Long-suffering, and kind.
  O could I stay !
 But I must reach the train at break of day.  I take my letters and the picture. Should  Your duties call you not so soon, oh wait,  See his dear head laid low by careful hand,  And say a prayer above the grave.
speaker: the maiden

utterance: How doth she innocently torture rack  My soul with hard realities ! I stand  And hear her talk of graves ! O God, the black,  Damp earth over my darling !
speaker: Helena

utterance:
Love, farewell !
 I kiss thee once. Lady, you do not mind ?
 It was but once. I would not seem unkind ;
  I would not wound you needlessly,  ii
speaker: the maiden

utterance: Proud heart, to bursting, but gainsay her not !
speaker: Helena

utterance: I know full well that yours the harder lot,  Dear lady ; but, forgive me, he was mine  Long, long before. It were too much to ask  That I should not be glad his heart returned  To me, his bride betrothed to know he yearned  For me before he died. I cannot mask  My joy because you loved him too.
speaker: the maiden

utterance: All joy that thou canst take; I would not rob  Thee of one little hair's-breadth.
speaker: Helena

utterance: Oh, farewell,  My love ! my love ! my love !
speaker: the maiden

utterance: Child, do not sob.  Come to me let me hold you ; who can tell,  Perhaps he hears you, though so still. We'll stand
speaker: Helena

utterance: The wagon's here.
speaker: WOMAN OF THE HOUSE

utterance: Alas ! and I must hasten. Kiss me, dear ;  Indeed, I love you now.
speaker: the maiden

utterance: To make you.
speaker: Helena

utterance: Meredith, art satisfied ?
speaker: Helena

utterance:
MARRIED ! Nay, now the little vexing fear  That troubled the calm hollow of my grief  With its small aching is withdrawn, and clear  The certainty she never loved him. Brief  Her forgetting brief! But I will not chide;

  All happiness go with thee, gentle bride,  And of my gold a sister's share !
  Towed  Another, and once his ! O golden head  Under the grass, how jealous is my heart  Of thy remembrance ! Yet I should be glad  She loved thee not, for then no evil part  I played, e'en though unconsciously.
  Oh, mad,
 Mad, mad my love for thee ! the same to-day  The same, the same. I could not be a wife  I could not stop the sun ! No love but thee,  My own, my own ! no kiss but thine no voice  To call me those sweet names that memory  Brings back with tears. Ah ! had I any choice,  I still must love thee down beneath the sod  More than all else though grandest soul that God  Had ever made did woo me. Love, my heart  Is thine, and ever must be thine ; thy name  Is branded there !
  Yet must I live my life.
speaker: Helena

utterance: The Count.
speaker: SERVANT

utterance:
Another ? Ah ! poor fools. The game
 WASHINGTON.
speaker: Helena

utterance: Show in the Count.
speaker: Helena

utterance: Madame ^Je viens
speaker: the count

utterance:
MY marriage-morning ! Lord, give me thy grace  For the new duties of a wedded life.
  The letters have I burned ;  And now the picture. Oh, dear boyish face,  One look the last ! Yet had I been thy wife,  Willie, I had been true to thee returned  All thy affection to the full.
  She said  Love was " a sacrifice." It is ; as thus :  Get thee behind me, Past !
speaker: the maiden

utterance: Which one of us  Was truest ? But why ask ? She wronged the dead  With many lovers nay, her very dress  Showed not one trace of sorrow.
speaker: the maiden

utterance:
I confess  I never thought her fair, although the throng  Do call her so, they tell me.
  Long, how long  I wore the heavy crape that checked my breath,  And went about as one who sorroweth ;  And I did sorrow ! Slow months passed, and I  Gave every thought to tearful memory ;  My grief grew selfish.
  Then he brought his suit  My mother wept and prayed. What right had I  To crush two lives ? If by the sacrifice  I make them happy, is it not large price  For my poor, broken years ? How earnestly  I strove to do the right !
  The patient fruit  Of years of prayer came to my aid, and now  I stand in bridal white. Lord, hear my vow :  Oh, may I make him happy ! Not a thought  Of any other love shall mar the troth  I give for this life. Evils, troubles, naught  But death, shall part us. Thus the marriage-oath.
 But after thenO Willie !
speaker: the maiden

utterance: Art thou dressed ?
speaker: the mother

utterance:
That's well, dear one. Never has mother blessed  A child more dutiful, more good.
  Come, love,  The bridegroom waits.
speaker: the mother
